    Differential Expression Analysis

    spata-v2-de-analysis.Rmd

    1. Introduction

    Differential expression analysis aims to discover quantitative changes in gene-expression levels between defined experimental groups. In SPATA2 these experimental groups are defined inside the feature data. More precisely: Every discrete variable that is part of the spata-object’s feature data assigns every sample’s barcode-spot to such an experimental group. This includes all spata-intern generated groups such as segmentation and clustering as well as any other discrete feature of your own extracted analysis that has been added via addFeatures(). See Extract, Add & Join data to learn how to do that with ease.

    # load packages 
library(SPATA2) 
library(tidyverse)

spata_obj <- loadSpataObject("data/spata-obj-gbm275.RDS")

    As mentioned in previous chapters SPATA2 makes use of some well written functions of the package Seurat which currently define the gold-standard of statistical scRNA-seq analysis in R. The function runDeAnalysis()is a wrapper around Seurat::FindAllMarkers() which finds the marker genes of the identity groups you denote with the across-argument. In the tutorial on segmentation and clustering in SPATA we created several grouping variables. Throughout this example we will try and find the differently expressed genes across the clusters of the "“Leiden_UMAP”" variable.

    plotSurface(object = spata_obj, 
            color_by = "Leiden_UMAP", 
            pt_clrp = "jama", 
            pt_size = 1.9
            )

    Figure 1.1 The chosen algorithm grouped the barcode spots in seven different clusters for which we are interested in their marker genes.

    2. Running the analysis

    The output of Seurat::FindAllMarkers() is a data.frame in which each row corresponds to a gene that turned out to be a marker gene for one of the identity groups. Additional variables provide information about it’s p-value, adjusted p-value, logFold change etc. runDeAnalysis() does not alter that output but stores it in the spata-object, more precisely in the @dea slot, short form for differential-expression-analysis. This feature allows to conveniently iterate over several methods like ‘wilcox’ or ‘bimod’ without loosing track of the results nor of the object- or variable-belonging. With printDeaOverview() you can check across which groups and according to which method de-analysis has already been conducted.

    spata_obj <- 
  runDeAnalysis(object = spata_obj,
                across = "Leiden_UMAP", # across which identity groups
                method_de = c("wilcox", "bimod") # with which methods
                )

# get an overview about the de-analysis results stored in your object
printDeaOverview(spata_obj)
    ## De-analysis has been performed on grouping variables:
## 
## - 'segmentation' with methods: wilcox
## - 'seurat_clusters' with methods: wilcox
## - 'Leiden_UMAP' with methods: wilcox' and 'bimod

    3. Extracting results

    There are two main functions with which you can manually extract the de-analysis results desired. First, getDeaResultsDf() returns the original resulting data.frame of Seurat::FindAllMarkers().

    getDeaResultsDf(object = spata_obj, 
                across = "Leiden_UMAP", 
                method_de = "wilcox")
    ## # A tibble: 5,971 x 7
##        p_val avg_logFC pct.1 pct.2 p_val_adj Leiden_UMAP gene  
##        <dbl>     <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>     <dbl> <fct>       <chr> 
##  1 1.66e-  4     299.  0.151 0.105 1   e+  0 Cluster 1   NPY   
##  2 3.26e- 57     264.  0.3   0.093 7.03e- 53 Cluster 1   TAC1  
##  3 7.68e- 34      92.6 0.173 0.05  1.66e- 29 Cluster 1   SST   
##  4 2.84e- 17      79.6 1     0.999 6.12e- 13 Cluster 1   GFAP  
##  5 1.38e- 12      36.3 1     0.999 2.97e-  8 Cluster 1   S100A6
##  6 1.86e-195      28.4 0.964 0.761 4.02e-191 Cluster 1   UCHL1 
##  7 0              17.1 0.966 0.461 0         Cluster 1   SNAP25
##  8 1.99e- 49      16.5 0.927 0.845 4.28e- 45 Cluster 1   TUBB2A
##  9 5.72e- 14      15.7 0.993 0.982 1.23e-  9 Cluster 1   TUBA1B
## 10 3.98e- 23      15.6 0.988 0.967 8.57e- 19 Cluster 1   UBB   
## # ... with 5,961 more rows

    The de-data.frame can be additionally processed such that the following steps are performed for every identity group. getDeaResultsDf() does that by calling the function filterDeaDf() which

    1. discards genes with avg_logFC-values that are either infinite or negative

    2. discards genes with adjusted p-values above the threshold set with max_adj_pval

    3. discard genes with log fold changes below the threshold set with min_lfc

    4. slices the data.frame in order that for every unique cluster of the cluster-variable:

    • the n genes with the highest avg_logFC-values are kept where n = n_highest_lfc

    • the n genes with the lowest p_val_adj-values are kept where n = n_lowest_pval

    1. arranges the genes according to the highest avg_logFC-values
    getDeaResultsDf(object = spata_obj, 
                across = "Leiden_UMAP", 
                method_de = "wilcox", 
                max_adj_pval = 0.025, # of every cluster take genes with an adj. p-value of 0.025 or lower
                n_lowest_pval = 20) # from the remaining genes take only to 'top 20')
    ## # A tibble: 105 x 7
##        p_val avg_logFC pct.1 pct.2 p_val_adj Leiden_UMAP gene   
##        <dbl>     <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>     <dbl> <fct>       <chr>  
##  1 1.86e-195     28.4  0.964 0.761 4.02e-191 Cluster 1   UCHL1  
##  2 0             17.1  0.966 0.461 0         Cluster 1   SNAP25 
##  3 1.35e-263     15.0  0.805 0.229 2.91e-259 Cluster 1   SYT1   
##  4 1.88e-165     13.6  0.9   0.619 4.05e-161 Cluster 1   ENC1   
##  5 4.46e-267     12.2  0.809 0.232 9.61e-263 Cluster 1   VSNL1  
##  6 3.03e-187     11.7  0.877 0.458 6.54e-183 Cluster 1   OLFM1  
##  7 5.72e-182     11.6  0.552 0.112 1.23e-177 Cluster 1   HPCA   
##  8 2.35e-139     11.4  0.895 0.608 5.07e-135 Cluster 1   YWHAH  
##  9 6.61e-191     10.0  0.911 0.511 1.42e-186 Cluster 1   RTN1   
## 10 5.66e-219      9.74 0.715 0.196 1.22e-214 Cluster 1   SLC17A7
## # ... with 95 more rows

    4. Plotting results

    4.1 Heatmap

    The gold standard of gene expression visualization is the classical heatmap. plotDeaHeatmap() does just that: visualizing the results of your de-analysis by refering to the results you would extract with getDeaResultsDf(). If you don’t want to refer to de-analysis results and just wish to plot certain genes of interest you can do that by passing them to the genes-argument.

    cluster_of_interest <- c("Cluster 2", "Cluster 3", "Cluster 6")

plotDeaHeatmap(object = spata_obj, 
               across = "Leiden_UMAP", # the grouping variable
               across_subset = cluster_of_interest, # the identity groups of interest 
               method_de = "wilcox", # the method with which the results were computed
               max_adj_pval = 0.025, # the adjusted p-value threshold
               n_lowest_pval = 20, 
               n_highest_lfc = 20, 
               clrp = "jama", 
               fontsize = 8)

    Figure 4.1 Heatmap visualizing the differentially expressed genes

    4.2 Dot plots

    An alternative are dot plots. These can be used to visualize differentially expressed genes with the function plotDeaDotPlot(). There are two main types between which can be switched using the argument by_group.

    plotDeaDotPlot(
  object = spata_obj, 
  across = "seurat_clusters", 
  across_subset = c("1", "2", "3", "4"),
  color_by = "avg_logFC",
  trans = "log10", # transform color scale with log10
  n_highest_lfc = 7,
  by_group = TRUE, # create separate plots for each specified group
  nrow = 2 # make sure that subplot are displayed in two rows
)

    Figure 4.2 Dot plot visualizing differentially expressed genes by group

    Using by_group = FALSE the results are merged to one plot.

    plotDeaDotPlot(
  object = spata_obj, 
  across = "seurat_clusters", 
  across_subset = c("5", "6", "7", "8"), 
  n_highest_lfc = 7,
  color_by = "avg_logFC",
  trans = "log",
  by_group = FALSE # merge in one plot
)

    Figure 4.3 Dot plot visualizing differentially expressed genes

    4.3 Statistic related plots

    There are additional ways to visualize the results of your de-analysis. As with almost all plotting functions in SPATA2 a vector of gene names is necessary for the function to know which genes to plot. getDeaGenes() is the second function to extract de-analysis results and a wrapper around getDeaResultsDf() that returns a vector gene names.

    genes_of_interest <-
  getDeaGenes(object = spata_obj,
              across = "Leiden_UMAP", # the grouping variable
              across_subset = cluster_of_interest, # the identity groups of interest 
              method_de = "wilcox", # the method with which the results were computed
              max_adj_pval = 0.025, # the adjusted p-value threshold
              n_lowest_pval = 10, 
              n_highest_lfc = 10
              )


head(genes_of_interest) # first six
    ## Cluster 2 Cluster 2 Cluster 2 Cluster 2 Cluster 2 Cluster 2 
##   "POSTN"  "TMSB4X"   "FABP7"   "RAMP1"  "PTPRZ1"   "S100B"
    tail(genes_of_interest) # last six
    ## Cluster 6 Cluster 6 Cluster 6 Cluster 6 Cluster 6 Cluster 6 
##  "EEF1A1"     "ADM"  "CHI3L1"     "CLU"  "TMSB10"     "UBC"

    A vector of gene names as returned by getDeaGenes() (or getGenes() for that matter) is a perfectly valid input for other plotting functions.

    high_threshold_markers <- 
    getDeaGenes(object = spata_obj,
                across = "Leiden_UMAP", 
                across_subset = cluster_of_interest, 
                method = "wilcox", 
                n_lowest_pval = 3
                ) # return only the two genes with the lowest p-value for every identity group

# print genes
high_threshold_markers
    ## Cluster 2 Cluster 2 Cluster 2 Cluster 3 Cluster 3 Cluster 3 Cluster 6 Cluster 6 
##   "POSTN"   "RAMP1"  "LANCL2"     "B2M"  "HSPA1A"  "MARCH6"     "ADM"   "VEGFA" 
## Cluster 6 
##  "HILPDA"
    # visualize statistics
plotBoxplot(object = spata_obj, 
            variables = high_threshold_markers, 
            across = "Leiden_UMAP", 
            across_subset = cluster_of_interest, 
            clrp = "jama", 
            nrow = 3
            ) + 
  legendTop()

    Figure 4.4 Plotting descriptive statistics with the analysis results

    4.3 Surface plots

    Another way to visualize your results would be to deploy plotSurfaceComparison().

    plotSurfaceComparison(object = spata_obj, 
                      color_by = high_threshold_markers, 
                      smooth = TRUE, 
                      pt_size = 1
                      ) + legendNone()

# compare to cluster localisation
plotSurface(object = spata_obj, 
            color_by = "Leiden_UMAP", 
            pt_clrp = "jama"
            )

    Figure 4.5 Surfaceplots visualizing the differentially expressed genes

    4.4 Basic overview

    To obtain a basic overview of the qualities and quantities of your analysis results use plotDeaGeneCount(), plotDeaLogFC() and plotDeaPvalues().

    plotDeaGeneCount(object = spata_obj, across = "Leiden_UMAP", method_de = "wilcox", clrp = "jama")

    Figure 4.6 Basic summary of your analysis results 

    plotDeaLogFC(object = spata_obj, across = "Leiden_UMAP", method_de = "wilcox", clrp = "jama")

    Figure 4.6 Basic summary of your analysis results 

    plotDeaPvalues(object = spata_obj,
               across = "Leiden_UMAP",
               method_de = "wilcox",
               clrp = "jama",
               plot_type = "density", 
               scales = "free")

    Figure 4.6 Basic summary of your analysis results
